dt: {bc}a chamber (such as a vault) wholly or partly underground
{bc}a vault under the main floor of a church

et: borrowed from Latin {it}crypta, crupta{/it} "covered passage, underground room," borrowed from Greek {it}kryptḗ{/it} "underground room," noun derivative from feminine of {it}kryptós{/it} "hidden, secret," verbal adjective of {it}krýptein{/it} "to hide, conceal," of uncertain origin

The verb {it}krýptein{/it} is phonetically and semantically close to {it}kalýptein{/it} "to cover, conceal," and the two may have influenced each other. Other forms with which {it}krýptein{/it} has been compared, such as Old Church Slavic {it}kryjǫ, kryti{/it} "to cover, hide, shroud," Lithuanian {it}kráuju, kráuti{/it} "to pile up," are too distant phonetically to allow realistic reconstruction of an Indo-European verbal base. The alternation in consonants between {it}kryp-{/it} (in {it}krýptein, kryptós{/it}), {it}kryb-{/it} (in {it}krýbdēn{/it} "secretly"), and {it}kryph-{/it} (in {it}kryphêi{/it} "in secret," {it}-kryphos{/it} "hidden") is apparently the result of both assimilation and analogy.
shortdef: a chamber (such as a vault) wholly or partly underground; especially : a vault under the main floor of a church
